item.title: Will
item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
If I die, I wish for the following:

  1. Donate all my usable organs to medical and/or scientific causes.
  2. Dispose my body to the sea. Wrap my body in preferably biodegradable material, attach some weights, and let it go to sink to the waters. This would be my final amendment with the sea, no longer burdened with fear of drowning. Let my epitaph be simple and hopefully witty still: “Pa-deep”
  3. If the above is not feasible for some reason, dispose of my body with as little cost, as little carbon footprint, and as little effort as possible.
  4. During my wake, play muzak. Sing songs of celebration and/or of mourning. If it’s possible, you can even have an open mic event where people can play songs and/or read poetry.

Hopefully, before I die, I would have you read these things first, so we would agree on how doable any of the points listed here.

DNR

If I am no longer able to communicate with the world in a meaningful way, that means I am either no longer alive or no longer wish to be.

If possible, I don’t want my last moments be in a hospital, raking in unwanted fees that might leave my loved ones to debt.

item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
During the peak of Friendster in our country, people displayed their testimonials. Many took acquiring them seriously. In the spirit of testi, and being the nostal-junkie that I am, the following are written affirmations from different people I have interacted with in some capacity. item.title: About Me
item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
I am a researcher and maker with over ten years of experience helping people and organizations understand there are better possibilities outside prevailing systems.

My greatest strength (so far) is writing stories and documenting learnings with the purpose of sharing them with others.

I am eager to improve the lives of people, myself included, in communities I am in, because I value the strength and power we possess as a collective in shaping the Here and Now that we want to live in.

I’ve always wanted to learn and make something. These days, that thing skews abstract, but I hope to create more tangible things using different tools (hardware and software alike) that might be useful. For R&R, I like to read movies and watch books to switch things up.

Sometimes, people say good things about me.

For my professional background check my CV or download the pdf version. References are available on request.

Contact

You can always contact me via email (see footer).

Some good icebreakers:

  • A reply/comment to one of the posts I made here
  • “What have you been reading?”
  • “You talked about [Something]. How do you/I/we act on [Something (related)]? Or, what are your thoughts on [This Other Thing]?”
  • “[An Interesting Event] will happen on [This Date] at [That Place]. Have you heard about it? I think you’d be interested.”
  • “If you liked listening to [Artist], you might enjoy listening to [This Other Artist] and/or [This Genre].

item.title: Default FOSS apps
item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
Default apps

  • Operating System: Alpine Linux v3.20 stable (laptop, daily driver); Debian 12 “bookworm” (host server); Android (smartphone)
  • Tiling window manager: sway
  • Web Browsers: Firefox (laptop), Mull (Android)
    • Browser add-ons: uBlock Origin, Redirector, SponsorBlock
    • Redirector set-up: JSON file (includes Scribe, Rural Dictionary, rimgo, Quetre)
  • Search engine: Searx
  • Password manager: Bitwarden
  • Email client: aerc
  • Email providers: Migadu, Tuta
  • Torrent client: Transmission
  • Back-up/File Sync: Syncthing
  • Instant messaging: Signal
  • RSS Feed reader: newsraft
  • Music player: Rhythmbox (laptop); Auxio (Android)
  • Internet radio: Shortwave
  • Video player: mpv
  • Notes: vimwiki plugged into neovim (also my $EDITOR of choice)
  • Office suite: LibreOffice
  • PDF reader: zathura
  • Physical exercise tracker: FitoTrack (Android)
  • YouTube client: NewPipe (Android)
  • Authenticator: Aegis (Android)

Special Mentions

  • Fedora Workstation – The first Linux distro I used. Also currently using the Budgie Spin to run on an old laptop repurposed to be a media center.
  • OpenBSD – The one I used in the Old Computer Challenge
  • Devuan 5 “Daedalus” – is a Debian-fork OS without systemd that used to be in my main computer before distro-hopping1 to Alpine.
  • LibreWolf – For a while, I had used this Firefox fork, but it was giving mild inconveniences in my new Alpine setup. So, I switched back to Firefox.
  • Tor Browser – For when I need to be anonymous on the internet. I don’t use this much, but I have it just in case.
  • Thunderbird - GUI email client I had used and is just reliable, though can be bloated at times.

Why?

Is the software you use…:

  • backed by venture capital (VC) funding?
  • maintained by Big Tech companies?

If so, know that this will pose different problems in the future, if it hasn’t already yet. Companies ultimately are driven by profit incentive, and at one point, they will want to collect. It can be in the form of unfair subscription payment models, enshittification of their services, privacy-invasive data gathering methods, etc.

As much as possible, I want to use FOSS (i.e., free and open source software) for all my software needs. I believe FOSS empowers me to accomplish digital tasks that don’t cage me in a paid walled garden and/or surveil my every move.

It can be hard, though, especially if Big Tech companies are embedded in our digital lives now (e.g., at work), whether we like it or not. Take this personal anecdote as an example: computer “lessons” from my high school days involved using proprietary software like Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint) and Adobe Photoshop. When these are baked into the curriculum early on, it won’t be easy learning about FOSS alternatives.

I try not to get obsessed, though, on picking the right tools. There’s no perfect tool, and even the great ones will not save you; how you use them might.

  1. The act of frequently changing the OS of one’s computer to a different distribution of Linux, usually as a hobby. ↩︎

item.title: Blogroll
item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
An incomplete list of blogs that I find interesting currently.

Ava
writes about their hobbies and projects, tech, health, Right to Repair, Car-free Cities, and other things that I vibe with.
Dan Luu
is a developer who deep-dives into various topics, including computer latencies, cocktail party ideas, and everything in between, housed in a barely-formatted website.
Em
likes writing, and people, and maybe writing about people, that maybe gut-punches the reader, but not in a horrible way.
Drew DeVault
is a developer, probably most known for coming up with Sway window manager, who also has important (controversial?) political takes related to FOSS.
Ethical Network
looks for ways to make the “ethical the new normal,” either by recommending more sustainable laptops or by de-googling one’s lifestyle.
False Knees
is an Art Tumblr, containing mostly webcomics about birds.
Gemma Copeland
is interested in and works on many things, including “imagin[ing] post-growth futures,” something I also find myself thinking about on a regular basis.
Hund
is a “slow-tech philosopher” who is into computer stuff. We align on many things computer-related, but I always find something to learn from them.
Hundred Rabbits
is a two-person artist collective who, most of the time, operates on their sailboat Pino, making art using some of their homebrewed FOSS.
Jag Talon
is a friend involved in mutual aid, Palestinian, environmental, abolitionist, and open source movements.
Low-tech Magazine
explores “past and often forgotten technologies and how they can inform sustainable energy practices” from their solar-powered server in Barcelona.
maia arson crimew
writes about cyberpunk, hacktivism, and other technical articles. I’m interested in their thoughts about cybersecurity in general.
Mandy Brown
talks about the more progressive practices that we could/should have in our workplaces.
Manu Moreale
loves (maybe) the Venn diagram of minimalism and web development, and often talks about the overlap of the two.
Solène Rapenne
likes to share her findings on niche operating systems like NixOS and BSDs.
The Amphibian
is an eco-anarchist’s “storytelling folded in with strategy,” involving lots of looking inward as well as outward.
The Perry Bible Fellowship
is a webcomics drawn by Nicholas Gurewitch with good art laced with a tinge of dark humor.
Winnie Lim
tries to lead a purposeless life and writes publicly about it such that I question myself when am I going to be deliberate about my aimlessness.

item.title: Ideas of Possible Projects
item.author: ohio@araw.xyz (ohio olarte)
item.description:
Doing side projects keep me sharp. In the process, I’ll try to document each step, and publish whatever findings I might have here for public (re)viewing.

Like many, my interests change over time, so the ideas listed here can’t be lumped into one big category. The length of list changes from time to time, depending on my current situation. “Life happens,” they say. I tend to agree.

Anyway, here is the list, in no particular order:

  1. Wifi antenna
  2. Soap from used oil
  3. Hand tools
  4. Computer monitor upcycled from an old laptop
  5. Laundry detergent
  6. Repair, refurbish, and/or repurposing of different consumer electronics
  7. Make a free and open-source software and hardware, but not necessarily found together in a single device, that a layperson would find useful
  8. Bio-digester
  9. Leather jacket made of mushrooms (mycelia jacket)
  10. Wearable dashcam, powered by body heat (using thermoelectric generator)

As soon as I start working on an idea here, it will be migrated to the Projects page.
